channel.title: Adobe Premiere Pro Notes on Leslie TANG
channel.description: Recent content in Adobe Premiere Pro Notes on Leslie TANG

item.title: About Sequence and Shortcut Keys
item.description: Shortcut Keys You can view the available short keys from Settings > Keyboard Shortcuts Ripple Trim w, q They basically cut, delete, and close the gap between the cut Add Cuts ctrl + k Increase Height of Audio and Video Track alt +/- : increase/decrease audio track height ctrl +/-: increase/decrease video track height Audio Gain Select the clip and use g Control Speed ctrl + r: to bring up the clip speed and duration panel

item.title: Premiere Pro Basic Workflow
item.description: I wrote down the steps from the class by Jordy Vandeput on Skillshare. For me, video edit is a pain, mainly because of the sheer number of actions in the UI. After going through the first video, I realized there is a logical design decision behind Adobe Premiere Pro. That logical flow becomes obvious, once you understand the general workflow. General Workflow All video edits start with the bin. The bin contains all the relevant resources.
